force.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a group of people who have been trained to do military work for a government or other organization
force.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: He strengthened US forces in the Gulf.
a plan to disarm the rebel forces (=those fighting against the government)
The riots were suppressed by government forces.
force.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: the army, navy, and air force
force.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Both her sons are in the forces.
force.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: military action used as a way of achieving your aims
force.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Peace cannot be imposed by force.
The UN will allow the use of force against aircraft violating the zone.
force.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: violent physical action used to get what you want
force.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: The police used force to overpower the demonstrators.
They kicked the door down using sheer brute force.
In the end he had to be thrown out of the house by force.
force.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: the amount of physical power with which something moves or hits another thing
force.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: He raised his hand and struck her with terrifying force.
The force of the explosion blew out all the windows.
force.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: powerful natural forces such as earthquakes, floods, and drought
force.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: a group of people who have been trained and organized to do a particular job
force.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: the quality of the teaching force
force.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: something or someone who is powerful and has a lot of influence on the way things happen
force.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: He’s a quick and decisive player – a force to be reckoned with (=a person, team, company etc that influences what happens).
The fall in prices was due to forces beyond their control.
Betty Coward was the driving force behind the project.
Healthy competition is a force for innovation.
force.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: the powerful effect that something has on you
force.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: Even after 30 years, the play has lost none of its force.
force.translation[0].definitions[10].def: a unit for measuring the strength of the wind
force.translation[0].definitions[11].def: extremely strong wind that does a lot of damage
force.translation[0].note_box[0].section: Israel refused to withdraw its armed forces from the area.
Several battles took place involving American forces.
Government forces reportedly shot dead 300 unarmed civilians.
The government claimed that the security forces had destroyed the rebels’ headquarters.
The village was attacked by rebel forces.
He served with the military forces during the war.
Should the European Union have its own defence force?
Enemy forces now occupy substantial areas of the city.
A large UN peacekeeping force is being assembled.
Special forces were employed to support the local army.
Her husband is in the forces.
He was too young to join the forces when the war broke out.
Expecting the Allies to attack again, he began to withdraw his forces eastward.
force.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to make someone do something they do not want to do
force.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Government troops have forced the rebels to surrender.
Due to the high cost of borrowing, many companies have been forced to close.
I had to force myself to get up this morning.
women who are forced into arranged marriages
Bad health forced him into taking early retirement.
force.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to make someone or something move in a particular direction or into a different position, especially through or using great strength
force.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Strong winds forced the ship off course.
Firemen tried to enter the building, but were forced back by the flames.
She tried to keep the door shut but the man forced it open.
force.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to make something happen or change, especially more quickly than planned or expected
force.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: the unfortunate events that forced his resignation
We need to force the pace on alternative energy policies.
The effect will be to increase unemployment and force down wages.
force.translation[1].note_box[0].items[0: You force someone to do something
The robbers forced him to hand over the money
force.translation[1].note_box[0].items[1: Force is often used in the passive
The minister was forced to resign because of the scandal
force.translation[1].note_box[0].items[2: The robbers made him hand over the money
force.translation[1].note_box[0].items[3: You compel someone to do something
The court can compel witnesses to give evidence
force.translation[1].note_box[0].items[4: Compel is very often used in the passive
He became seriously ill and was compelled to retire two years later
force.translation[1].note_box[0].items[5: You say that someone is obliged to do something Oblige is almost always used in the passive
Hotels are obliged by law to install smoke alarms
force.translation[1].note_box[1].section: to make someone do something they do not want to do. Used when people or situations make you do something
They were beaten and forced to confess to crimes they had not committed.
The drought forced millions of farmers to sell their cattle.
to force someone to do something by using pressure, threats, or violence. Make somebody do something  is more common than force somebody to do something in everyday English
Her parents disapproved of Alex and they made her stop seeing him.
Two men with guns made the staff hand over the money.
pressure
to try to force someone to do something by making them feel that they should do it
Some employers pressure their staff into working very long hours.
She felt they were trying to pressurize her into getting married.
blackmail
to force someone to give you money or do what you want by threatening to tell embarrassing secrets about them
She tried to blackmail him with photographs of them together at the hotel.
compel
to force someone to do something using official power or authority. Also used when someone has to do something because of their situation
The town was surrounded and compelled to surrender.
I felt compelled to offer them some kind of explanation.
You are compelled by law to carry an ID card.
coerce
to force someone to do something by threatening them
Local people were coerced into joining the rebel army.
be obliged to do something
if someone is obliged to do something, they must do it because it is the law or the rule, or because of the situation they are in
You are not obliged to say anything which may harm your defence in court.
They were obliged to sell the land.
force.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a group of people who have been trained and organized for a particular purpose
force.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Our division has expanded its sales force (=the people in a company who sell the company’s products) to 160.
force.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: if a law or rule is in force, it exists and must be obeyed
force.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: These regulations have been in force since 1997.
New EU directivescome into force (=start to operate) in April.
force.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: something or someone that has a strong influence on an activity or the way events develop
force.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: She is the driving force (=person or thing that has the strongest influence on the way things happen) behind the group’s creation.
The group is certainly a force to be reckoned with (=has a lot of power and influence) in the publishing industry.
force.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: the way that the behaviour of buyers and sellers affects the levels of SUPPLY AND DEMAND in a particular market, especially when the government does nothing to change this
force.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: By ending the electricity monopoly, market forces rather than state utilities will set prices.

Whether there is enough demand to sustain all of the car manufacturers is a question we will have toleave to market forces (=allow market forces to take effect so that the market works in the most efficient way).
force.translation[2].definitions[4].exam: The City’s code of practice does not have the force of law.  (=the same authority as the law)
force.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: if a situation forces you to do something, it makes you do it, even though you do not want to
force.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: Massive debts have forced them to close the store.
We were forced to raise prices because of increased costs.
force.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: to make something happen against the wishes of the people who are affected
force.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: The imposition of VAT would force the closure of 20% of regional newspapers.
